scenarios.title: Supporting a Loved One
scenarios.narrator: Your close friend or family member is going through a difficult time, and you want to be there for them. You need to understand the best ways to offer support.

questions.text: Your loved one confides in you about their struggles. What is your first response?

options.text: Listen attentively and acknowledge their feelings.
options.feedback: Listening and acknowledging their feelings shows empathy and understanding.

options.text: Immediately offer advice on how to solve their problems.
options.feedback: Offering advice too soon can seem dismissive of their feelings.

options.text: Compare their situation to your own past experiences.
options.feedback: This can make them feel like their problems are being minimized.

options.text: Change the subject to lighten the mood.
options.feedback: Changing the subject can make them feel like their feelings are not important.

questions.text: They express feeling overwhelmed and unable to cope. How do you respond?

options.text: Encourage them to take things one step at a time and offer your help.
options.feedback: This shows your willingness to support them in manageable ways.

options.text: Tell them to toughen up and deal with it.
options.feedback: This response can come off as insensitive and unsupportive.

options.text: Avoid the topic because it makes you uncomfortable.
options.feedback: Avoiding the topic can make them feel more isolated.

options.text: Suggest they should have handled things differently.
options.feedback: This can make them feel criticized rather than supported.

questions.narrator: You notice that your loved one is withdrawing from social activities.
questions.text: What is a supportive way to address this?

options.text: Invite them to a low-pressure activity and respect their response.
options.feedback: Inviting them to a low-pressure activity shows you care without putting too much pressure on them.

options.text: Tell them they need to get out more and be social.
options.feedback: This can come off as pushy and insensitive to their current state.

options.text: Ignore the behavior and hope it changes.
options.feedback: Ignoring the behavior can make them feel more isolated.

options.text: Scold them for avoiding social activities.
options.feedback: Scolding can make them feel worse about their situation.

questions.narrator: Your loved one starts talking about their problems more openly.
questions.text: How do you keep the conversation supportive?

options.text: Continue to listen without judgment and offer encouragement.
options.feedback: Listening without judgment and offering encouragement helps them feel supported.

options.text: Tell them they are overreacting.
options.feedback: This minimizes their feelings and can damage trust.

options.text: Change the subject to avoid discomfort.
options.feedback: Changing the subject can make them feel their problems are being ignored.

options.text: Give them a step-by-step plan to fix everything.
options.feedback: Offering a plan too soon can seem like you're not really listening.

questions.narrator: They mention feeling hopeless about their situation.

options.text: Express your concern and suggest seeking professional help if needed.
options.feedback: Expressing concern and suggesting professional help shows you care and understand the seriousness of their feelings.

options.text: Tell them to snap out of it.
options.feedback: This is dismissive and can make them feel worse.

options.text: Downplay their feelings to try and make them feel better.
options.feedback: Downplaying their feelings can make them feel invalidated.

options.text: Ignore their statement and talk about something else.
options.feedback: Ignoring their statement can make them feel unheard and unsupported.
